content:
Consider the discrete category 222 with two objects, called o1o_1o1​ and o2o_2o2​. These objects are pretty similar, intuitively, even though they are not isomorphic. In fact, there is an automorphism (an invertible endofunctor) α:2→2\alpha: 2 \to 2α:2→2 that swaps the two objects, so that in particular α(o1)=o2\alpha(o_1) = o_2α(o1​)=o2​.

Now consider a functor F:2→CF: 2 \to CF:2→C. Then, it is not required by the definition of a functor that F(o1)≅F(o2)F(o_1) \cong F(o_2)F(o1​)≅F(o2​). I think it is also not required that there exist an automorphism β:C→C\beta: C \to Cβ:C→C so that β(F(o1))=F(o2)\beta(F(o_1)) = F(o_2)β(F(o1​))=F(o2​), or even that β(F(o1))≅F(o2)\beta(F(o_1)) \cong F(o_2)β(F(o1​))≅F(o2​).

Sometimes I think of a functor F:D→CF: D \to CF:D→C as realizing the structure of DDD as part of CCC. The situation described above seems to go against this philosophy: o1o_1o1​ and o2o_2o2​ are related in a certain way in 222, but F(o1)F(o_1)F(o1​) and F(o2)F(o_2)F(o2​) are not necessarily related in a similar way in CCC.

Is there a name given to functors that do have the property I discuss above? That is, is there a name for functors F:D→CF: D \to CF:D→C so that for any automorphism α:D→D\alpha: D \to Dα:D→D and any objects ddd and d′d'd′ in DDD so that α(d)=d′\alpha(d) = d'α(d)=d′, there then exists an automorphism β:C→C\beta: C \to Cβ:C→C so that β(F(d))=F(d′)\beta(F(d)) = F(d')β(F(d))=F(d′)?

It might be more principled to ask that this only hold up to isomorphism. So, I would also be interested in considering a relaxed version of this condition: Is there a name for functors F:D→CF: D \to CF:D→C so that for any automorphism α:D→D\alpha: D \to Dα:D→D and any objects ddd and d′d'd′ in DDD so that α(d)≅d′\alpha(d) \cong d'α(d)≅d′, there then exists an automorphism β:C→C\beta: C \to Cβ:C→C so that β(F(d))≅F(d′)\beta(F(d)) \cong F(d')β(F(d))≅F(d′)?

(A follow-up thought: Maybe things would be nicer if I didn't consider automorphisms of categories, but instead equivalences of a category with itself.)

I don't think this is really about categories, actually. Groups, for instance, have the same behavior you complain about, where the existence of an automorphism of CCC sending g1g_1g1​ to g2,g_2,g2​, which certainly says there's something similar about g1g_1g1​ and g2g_2g2​ in C,C,C, doesn't imply the same for F(g1),F(g2)F(g_1),F(g_2)F(g1​),F(g2​) when F:C→DF:C\to DF:C→D is a homomorphism. (Note that I'm using your notation but there's a level shift here, if we think about groups as categories: g1,g2g_1,g_2g1​,g2​ are morphisms.)

Whether in groups or categories, I'm not really sure how to think about your proposed condition. It seems awkward to work just one object at a time. Maybe it would be more natural (without messing up your motivating example) to ask that for any automorphism α\alphaα there exist β\betaβ such that β∘F=F∘α\beta\circ F=F\circ\alphaβ∘F=F∘α? It's hard for me to see what this property means, though, except in the case that FFF is an isomorphism or an equivalence, where it's always possible by setting α=F−1βF.\alpha=F^{-1}\beta F.α=F−1βF.

This kind of property is more commonly considered as a property of the codomain rather than the functor. There are concepts in model theory of homogeneous object (relative to some class of objects). The "random graph" is an example of this: given any finite graph and two embeddings of that graph into the random graph (or equivalently, given two isomorphic subgraphs), there is an automorphism of the random graph exchanging them.
Actually, maybe "ultrahomogeneous" is the term I should be using for this property. Here's a MO question about those.

Incidentally, a related property studied by Ehresmann and Vanbremeersch (leading to their definition of "multiplicity principle") appears in a paper I am currently reviewing. Hopefully that gives you some keywords to search for.

Thanks to both of your for your interesting responses! After thinking about them for a bit, I feel like I understand what's going on here a little better. I appreciate the reference to the concept of "ultrahomogeneous" in model theory.

I think it makes sense to me that this kind of property is more often considered as a property of the codomain. I suppose it's actually quite a lot to ask that automorphisms α\alphaα of DDD extend to automorphisms β\betaβ of CCC for F:D→CF: D \to CF:D→C. Intuitively, for some object d∈Dd \in Dd∈D, F(d)F(d)F(d) and (F∘α)(d)(F \circ \alpha)(d)(F∘α)(d) might be connected to other parts of CCC in different ways, which starts adding in extra conditions (relating to the structure of CCC) for any automorphism of CCC that sends F(d)F(d)F(d) to (F∘α)(d)(F \circ \alpha)(d)(F∘α)(d).

By the way, this question occurred to me while I was thinking about limits. I was wondering if lim⁡F\lim FlimF and lim⁡(F∘α)\lim (F \circ \alpha)lim(F∘α) are necessarily isomorphic if they both exist, for α\alphaα an invertible endofunctor. I am still hoping this might be true!
yes, in general any equivalence α \alpha α would give you an isomorphism of limits
